reviews.review_msg: Sarah is an amazing prof. She is super passionate and cares for her students. The course was tough but it's not hard to get a good grade if you participate and engage with the tutorial readings. She's very approachable and will give great feedback and connect with you during office hours, highly recommend!

Dr. Walshaw is an incredible professor! She is understanding and kind. She structures her class in a way that requires lots of participation, but has no exams and is very lenient on due dates. She is fun to talk to and encourages office hour chats. However, I felt the class content was somewhat all over the place (but its not tested so no biggie).

Sarah is so caring but I felt as though the actual content was all over the place/hard to understand and only having one in-person 50-minute lecture a week lowered the quality of this course. Sarah is passionate about her teaching and I imagine going to see her more often would have made this class go over smoother for me. (Must buy textbook!!!)

Pro: Passionate, cares about students, available if you have any questions, good TA who also cares. Advice: If you don't understand the material prior to exams, ask for help. You don't need to read the full chapters; focus on the main points and primary sources. Cons: It is very hard to get full marks on papers. Tests: written answer, reasonable.
Dr Walshaw is an okay professor. Her exam questions are overcomplicated and she marks tough. It's an okay class, she barley gives full marks ever.

Sarah is super super kind, lovely, and extremely accessible outside of class.  She really cares about the subject matter and her students.  That being said, I'm not sure I learned anything in her class.  HIST146 is quite surface level and the way content delivered was not super effective in building my confidence with the subject matter.
see below delete this one

Who would interpret: 80 men hung for protesting slow starvation as "justice"; Ethiopia defeating Italy as a "dire ramification" of comparable armaments; colonialism limited by "poor" military performance? Aligns with the single story of European superiority; confusing, depressing, but very friendly & accessible
potential for professorial excellence

Sarah is an amazing prof and I really enjoyed this course. She is extremely accessible outside of class whether it's her office hours or via email! She explains assignments extremely thoroughly as well as course material. I'm not even a history major but I would take all of the history courses with her if i could!

Sarah was an amazing professor! She was always available outside of class to help and was clear about what her exams would be like. Some of the course work can be boring as she uses a textbook, but her tutorials are engaging and if you don't understand a concept, she will break it down step by step. I would definitely recommend her as a prof.

Ummm how is Sarah's average rating any less than 4.0?! Sarah is genuinely the kindest prof I've ever had. You can tell she truly cares about the content she teaches and also the wellbeing of her students. I'm usually an A average student but with Sarah she really made me work for it, lol. Biggest tip: One-on-one meetings with Sarah is your FRIEND!

I wanted to take this coarse because I wanted to learn more about African history. Sarah did a good job at teaching and relied on a lot of local African sources which was great to see! She is a bit of a speedy talker though so it can be hard to keep up. But other than that she was helpful, approachable and a fair marker.

Sarah is one of my favourite profs ever. She is incredibly caring and understanding and is very accessible outside of class (she even goes as far as to give out her personal cell). She is very passionate about the information she teaches, and this translates into engaging and thought provoking discussions. A class with her is a must!

Sarah is a great prof. This was my second class with her. She works hard to get your marks in fast and is always available to chat and work with you. All her classes include 'scaffolding' so that your entire grade is not decided by a project, and that she can help you throughout your projects.
Really kind/caring prof. Sometimes the lectures can be dry, but she does her best to help and teach. Great prof overall!
She's ok. Good lectures here and there. Not my go-to prof.

Dr. Walshaw, although vague with certain aspects of feedback, is a solid prof to take. She's accommodating if you need an extension. For some reason we had three groups of high school students attend our lectures throughout this semester. Lots of reading so you need a solid work ethic. Interesting class, but a fair amount of work to do
Great teacher, enthusiastic, caring and fun. She really liked having group projects/discussions in the tutorials, which can be annoying if you don't like group work.

Sarah tries her best to make students feel comfortable and engaged with the material she teaches, but her expectations are high for papers and participation. She expects students to come to class analyzing the readings she assigns thoroughly. This has been possibly one of the hardest courses I've taken so far at SFU.

Sarah is a really nice and caring person, but she is not as great as a prof. Her lectures lack guidance and specifics and her feedback is extremely limited--the only bit of feedback I received on an assignment was "nice job," but I got a B. I think she struggles to translate her passion for the subject into concise and informational lectures.

I would not recommend her to anyone that isn't majoring in history or archaeology. The course is extremely challenging to follow if you do not have a strong background in African history. I felt lost and confused the entire time.

Dr. Walshaw is a great lecturer, and is very caring. She makes a great effort to ensure that lectures are understandable and that help is easily accessed. Try to get her for tutorials though - found her TA to be very unorganized and kind of lost. Overall, she did a great job with this course and I would definitely take her again! Records lectures.

Dr. Walshaw is an approachable teacher who appears to care for her students; however, her grading expectations are too high. Her tests are fair, but her marking on them will be a surprise. Received my lowest mark in history in her class by far. Will avoid taking another class with her due to her unreasonable high expectations.

Her kind personality is deceiving. Marks as if she is teaching a masters class. I have taken 4th year classes that were much easier and fair. And she does not grade fairly at all. DO NOT take any classes with her.

Lectures related to the readings but don't cover nowhere near as much ground. Focus on lecture material and take loose notes on the textbook. Sort of "up in the air" feeling throughout the semester, didn't feel very structured.

Sarah is one of the kindest professors I've had at SFU. She goes out of her way to get to know everyone's name, and was always super friendly which I appreciated. Despite what others have said below, I found her assignments and grading to be pretty fair. My only complaint would be that she took FOREVER to mark stuff, and she gave little feedback

She is passionate, knowledgable and kind. However, her lectures are not the easiest to follow and  her powerpoints are useless. A lot of dry readings but they were at least 90% relevant. Difficult marker and does not give the most clear instructions.
Decent professor. Enjoys the stuff. Lectures are sort of rambling and unrelated to the textbook usually.
Not a fan
Wouldn't take again, prof is nice but material dry
Pretty boring content and took way too long to get back on assignments

Overall very interesting course material an very enthusiatic lectures to make a subject you would think of as boring very intetesting and engaging.  Although it took a while to get assignments back, feedback was more than sufficient.   Would take once of her courses again if possible!
Loved Sarah's lectures! I found her interests in food history really engaging, but too many readings for a 100 level course, and none of them were very interesting.
Nice prof didn't mind her lectures, slow at some points but overall good.  Challenge was with assignments, made the course not worth taking
dont do it

She takes too long to give any feedback on assignments so it's difficult to gage where you're at in this class, also more of an archeology course.  Really only take it you are super interested in the history of bananas, yams, baobab leaves OR most exciting, rice.  Would not take again.

She's amazing. This is a survey course, lots to pack in and boy did she pack them in. She's kind, approachable, clearly knows a lot but is humble enough to open it up to the class and is willing to listen and challenge your views. If you come from a non-arts background, history is a bit challenging in that it's open-ended and loose, so do readings!

She's nice and is available outside of class. However, she expects a lot out of you, so you will need to keep on top of readings. Her powerpoint are useless. Her lectures are unorganized and sometimes make no sense. She grades your work as if you should have the same amount of knowledge as her on the topic, so this class is HARD. Don't recommend.

LOVE HER! Sarah is amazing.. one of the best profs at SFU. She knows her stuff and is always clear on what she's looking for. I wasn't super into the topic before, but her passion is contagious. Lectures aren't mandatory for passing, but they're always too interesting to miss. Will definitely be taking another class with her. HIGHLY recommend her.

Although a kind teacher clearly passionate about African history, her lectures are very unclear and unless you go to class her slides make zero sense. She goes over too much material too quickly without enough explanation. She almost expects you to already have done research before class. Love history but wouldn't take another class with her.

I am not a History major but I definitely enjoyed taking HIST231 with Dr. Walshaw. She is one of the smartest professors I've had and it shows in her lectures and tutorials. She is a tough marker and makes you earn your grade, but I came to love working hard to earn my marks. Definitely have a lot of respect for her. She's a great prof.

Seriously the best prof I've ever had, taken two classes with her so far and taking one with her next term.  Tough marker, but is very helpful.  If you get an opportunity to take a class with her, do not miss out on the opportunity
very nice prof! would take more classes with her if i could, my favourite prof at sfu so far

Sarah is without a doubt the best prof i have had in my entire academic career at SFU. Super helpful she made the effort to see you her and i met for lunch to discuss a paper and she paid and talked and with me about my paper for an hour. She really wants everyone to do well, firm but fair marker. She is more than willing to help you.

Nice person, enthusiastic about class. But I found her style and organization lacking. It was difficult to write notes when she jumps between topics as much as she does. She wasn't overly helpful when I spoke with her in her office hours. I'd take a course with her only if you need the easy credit, but if you want more, look elsewhere.

One of the most interesting classes I took at SFU. The lecture slides are related to the readings from the textbook and the articles assigned weekly. She is very helpful and listens to students. I would definitely recommend her class and take with her other classes. Plus the TAs are very helpful. Just do the readings. You will be fine.

Fantastic professor! She really wants her students to succeed; always available for help and goes out of her way.  Learnt a lot during 13 weeks and highly recommend taking a course with her to fulfill a B-Hum requirement or just for an interesting course and great professor!

She's a good prof and really helpful, smart and loves what she does, but talks fast and hard to understand. Her powerpoint notes are useless without her, so don't copy them down word by word because they won't make any sense later unless you write down a lot of what she says too to go along with them. Overall enjoyed the course. VERY hard marker.
Talks a little fast, and exams are quite difficult, but if you're interested in the subject and willing to work hard, it's a great class!
exams made me want to shoot myself. super difficult. this is a first year class....
An awesome course and an equally awesome prof. Very interesting course material and readings. Defiantley not an easy course but was worth it. I'd take another course with her easily.

This class had alot of assignments and Sarah is a hard marker.  However, she is very willing to help and wants everyone to do well.  What I especially liked was your opinion didn't have to match hers to get a good grade, as long as you could back up what you were saying.  "Africa in the News" was my favourite part of the class.
Really nice! Class was pretty difficult but she was very willing to help!
Great prof, pretty nice and def knows her stuff. Make use of her office hours, she'll really help. Lectures can be a bore and material can seem choppy. Pretty simple midterm and final
Sarah is an excellent prof and cute as a button! She is very energetic and interested in her subject. To the person who rated her badly: stop being such a troll.

Sarah is a good prof.  She is interested in her subject material, and interested in seeing her students do well. Lectures are clear and organized, however, she moves fast, so be prepared to write a lot of notes, and remember a lot of information for the midterms.

A clear and charismatic professor who is very interested in the subject material.  She encourages discussion in class and tutorials and is extremely well organized and helpful.  I'd take a class with her again.

Took 3 courses with her in last 2 semesters, brilliant prof. Very clear and visibly interested in African History. Arrives at every class enthusiastic! She wants everyone in the class to do well.Take a course with her if you can!

best professor ive had so far, kept lectures and tutorials interesting and fun. quite a lot of assignments and midterms, but overall i really enjoyed this course and hope to take a class with prof. walshaw again in the future.
Terrible professor, zero charisma. Basically, just a completely unlikable person. Many people ask her questions which she could not answer. She made me much less interested in South African history.
Sarah is one of the best profs I've had. She gets the info out and doesn't bore you. She is very helpful and super nice. She has also let a few swear words slip... funny lady!

Super nice prof but is an Anthropology teacher & likes to talk about plants. If you can get around that, she's really helpful, interested in what you have to say, and tries to make the class & lecture interesting. New prof, so sticks to the rules (ie midterm, essay, final). Overall, would recommend her & take a class with her again.
